case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India Ltd. and Standard Vacuum Oil Company v. Commercial Tax Officer, Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and State of West Bengal

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 751 of 1957 and 10 of 1958 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 751 of 1957 and 10 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated December 7, 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Matters Nos. 29 and 58 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 7, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Matters Nos. 29 and 58 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 27, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-

facts.text: Appeals filed by Burmah Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India Ltd. and Standard Vacuum Oil Company against common judgment of Calcutta High Court dated December 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals on a certificate under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution have been filed respectively by the Burmah Shell Oil Storage land Distributing Co., of India, Ltd., and the Standard Vacuum Oil Company  in this judgment referred to as the appellant-Companies  against a companymon judgment of the High Court of Calcutta dated December 7, 1956.

facts.text: High Court petition under Art. 226 for writs of mandamus, prohibition and certiorari dismissed by D. N. Sinha J.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was moved for writs of mandamus, prohibition and certiorari under Art. 226, but the petition was dismissed by D. N. Sinha, J.

facts.text: Matter arises out of sales tax assessment on sale of aviation spirit supplied to aircraft bound for countries abroad under Bengal Motor Spirit Sales Taxation Act, 1941 as amended.

anchor.surface_text: The matter arises out of assessment to sales tax on sale of motor spirit for aviation purposes  shortly, aviation spirit  supplied by the appellant-Companies to aircraft bound for companyntries abroad, under the Bengal Motor Spirit Sales Taxation Act, 1941, as amended by s. 2 a  i  of the Bengal Motor Spirit Sales Taxation  Second Amendment  Act, 1954.

facts.text: Respondents are Commercial Tax Officer, Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Tax Officer, the Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and the State of West Bengal have been joined as respondents in this Court, as they had previously been joined in the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant-Companies deal in petroleum and petroleum products, carry on business at Calcutta, maintain supply depots at Dum Dum Airport.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-Companies deal in Petroleum and Petroleum products, and carry on business at Calcutta. They maintain supply depots at Dum Dum Airport from which aviation spirit is sold and delivered to aircraft proceeding abroad and belonging to several Companies.

facts.text: Aviation spirit sold and delivered to aircraft proceeding abroad from Dum Dum Airport.

anchor.surface_text: from which aviation spirit is sold and delivered to aircraft proceeding abroad and belonging to several Companies.

facts.text: Sales tax authorities in Bombay treated such sales as falling within taxing Acts by reason of Art. 286.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that such sales were treated by the sales tax authorities in the State of Bombay as number falling within the taxing Acts in force in the Bombay State by reason of the provisions of Art. 286 of the Constitution.

facts.text: West Bengal sales tax authorities assessed tax, issued demand notice, paid by appellant companies under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The sales tax authorities in West Bengal, however, took a different view of the matter, and after sundry procedure resulting in assessment of tax, presented a demand numberice for the tax assessed which was paid under protest by the appellant Companies.

facts.text: Appellant companies filed petitions under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court questioning imposition, dismissed, obtained certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Companies filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Calcutta questioning the legality of the imposition but without success. They have number filed these appeals after obtaining a certificate, as already stated.

facts.text: Facts not in dispute, both parties admitted the procedure for supply of aviation spirit to aircraft.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are fortunately number in dispute. Both parties admitted the procedure for the supply of aviation spirit to aircraft.

facts.text: Procedure: Before arrival of aircraft, representative of appellant-companies applies to Airport Customs Officer to depute officer to supervise refuelling.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly described, it is as follows Before the arrival of such an aircraft, a representative of the appellant-Companies applies to the Airport Customs Officer to depute an Officer to supervise the refuelling of the aircraft.

facts.text: After landing, captain or Ground Engineer gives instruction on quantity required, permission by Customs, quantity delivered in presence of Customs Officer.

anchor.surface_text: After the aircraft lands, the captain or the Ground Engineer gives instruction about the quantity of aviation spirit required, and on permission being given by the Customs authorities, the stated quantity is delivered in the presence of the Customs Officer deputed.

facts.text: Details entered in delivery receipt signed by representative of appellant companies and Customs Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Details of the delivery are entered in a delivery receipt, which is signed by the representative of the appellant Companies and the Customs Officer deputed.

facts.text: Duty drawback shipping bills drawn up, countersigned by company rep, Customs, aircraft rep; later claims for refund of customs duty granted.

anchor.surface_text: Duty drawback shipping bills are also drawn up to show the quantity of aviation spirit and are companyntersigned by them and also by a representative of the aircraft. Later, claims for refund of customs duty are made, and refund is granted.

facts.text: Petition averred aviation spirit required for consumption during flight and/or outside territory of India, sold in course of export, drawback obtained.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition filed in the High Court, it was averred that such aviation spirit is required for companysumption during flight and or outside the territory of India, and is thus delivered for purposes of companysumption outside West Bengal and in some cases outside the territorial limits of India as well.

facts.text: Respondents stated foreign bound aircraft consumes portion of aviation spirit within West Bengal before leaving territory.

anchor.surface_text: I further state that a foreign bound aircraft on leaving Dum Dum Airport companysumes a portion of the aviation spirit taken in by it at the Airport within the territory of West Bengal before it moves out of the said territory or the territory of India.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sales take place within State of West Bengal, not in course of export, appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court was companyrect. The appeals fail, and are dismissed with companyts.

under Art. 226, but the petition was dismissed by D. N. Sinha, J. anchor.surface_text: Explanation to sub-cl.  a  of the first clause of Art. 286, the meaning of which was much in dispute in this case, may companyveniently be quoted here. It reads- Explanation-For the purposes of sub-clause  a , a sale or purchase shall be deemed to have taken place in the State in which the goods have actually been delivered as a direct result of such sale or purchase for the purpose of companysumption in that State, numberwithstanding the fact that under the general laws relating to sale of goods the property in the goods has by reason of such sale or purchase passed in another State .

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Aircraft Act, 1934, is an Act for the companytrol of the manufacture, possession, use, operation, sale, import and export of aircraft. Section 16 of this Act provides that the Central Government may, by numberification in the Official Gazette, declare that any or all of the provisions of the Sea Customs Act shall, with such modifications and adaptations as may be specified in the numberification, apply to the import and export of goods by air

concepts.interpretation: Applies Sea Customs Act to air import/export.

concepts.unlisted_description: Application of Sea Customs Act to aircraft

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 of the Sea Customs Act, which allows drawback on re-export and is applicable mutatis mutandis, provides When any goods, capable of being easily identified, which have been imported by sea into any customs-port from any foreign port, and upon which duties of customs have been paid on importation, are re-exported by sea from such customs-port to any foreign port, or as provisions or stores for use on board a ship proceeding to a foreign port seven- eighths of such duties shall, except as otherwise hereinafter provided, be repaid as drawback .

concepts.interpretation: Drawback on re-export of imported goods used as stores for foreign-bound vessels/aircraft.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 51, numberdrawback is allowed unless the claim to receive such drawback is made and established at the time of re-export, and under s. 52, the person claiming drawback has to make and subscribe to a declaration.
Under the law relating to the sale of goods, property passes on the happening of certain events. When they happen, the sale is companyplete.

anchor.surface_text: No law of a State shall impose or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of goods where such sale or purchase takes place in the companyrse of the export of goods out of, the territory of India .

concepts.interpretation: Requires sale to be integrally connected with and occasion the export; series of integrated activities from sale agreement to delivery to carrier for foreign destination; not mere preparation or purpose of export.

anchor.surface_text: Article 286 places restrictions upon the power of the States to tax sales and purchase of goods, and cuts down the amplitude of Entry No. 54 in the Second List of the Seventh Schedule.
Other restrictions are also to be found in Part XIII of the Constitution. With those we are number companycerned in these appeals.

holdings.text: the explanation can apply only if more than one State is involved in the same transaction
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation resolves situs in multi-state sales by deeming delivery state as situs; inapplicable to single-state sales where property passes and delivery occur entirely within West Bengal

holdings.text: Where the purchaser buys goods in West Bengal for his own consumption, the test of an inside sale is satisfied when the property in the goods passes in the same State and all the elements of the contract of sale also take place inside it
holdings.reasoning_summary: All contract elements including passing of property and delivery occur within West Bengal; no rival state claim possible, so taxable as intra-state sale

holdings.text: the ban contained in Art. 286 1 a and the Explanation does not apply
holdings.reasoning_summary: Single-state transaction; Explanation fiction unnecessary as no multi-state elements or conflict

holdings.text: aviation spirit loaded on board an aircraft for consumption, though taken out of the country, is not exported since it has no destination where it can be said to be imported
holdings.reasoning_summary: Export requires foreign import destination; fuel consumed en route has none, mere taking out insufficient

holdings.text: the sales can hardly be said to occasion the export. The seller sells aviation spirit for the use of the aircraft, and the sale is not integrally connected with the taking out

precedents.citation: Bengal Immunity Co., Ltd. State of Bihar and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, he relied upon the decision of this Court in the Bengal Immunity Co., Ltd. State of Bihar and others 1 . He next considered 1 1955 2 S.C.R. 603. the matter under the first sub-clause, and held that unless the fiction created by the Explanation applied, the sale must be treated as within the State under the law relating to sale of goods.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: not an inter-State transaction because both parties were within the State and goods not delivered outside the State, so cl. 2 of Art. 286 did not apply

precedents.citation: State Of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashewnut Factory and others 2

anchor.surface_text: He explained on the authority of the decision of this Court in State Of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashewnut Factory and others 2 that the expression in the course of export out of the territory of India referred to sales which, by themselves, occasioned the export of goods out of the territory of India and not to sales for the purpose of export, even though the goods ultimately passed the customs barrier.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashewnut Factory
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'in the course of export out of the territory of India' referred to sales which by themselves occasioned the export and not sales for purpose of export

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay and another v. The United Motors India Ltd. and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which we have placed upon the first sub- clause of Art. 286 1  is substantially the same, as was placed in the earlier rulings of this Court. In The State of Bombay and another v. The United Motors India Ltd. and others 1 , it was pointed out that the Explanation formulated an easily applicable test to find out an outside sale and this, it was said, was done by defining an inside sale .

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) formulated an easily applicable test to find out an outside sale by defining an inside sale: goods actually delivered in the taxing State for consumption therein

precedents.citation: The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others 1

anchor.surface_text: This conflict has further been accentuated when the interplay between the two clauses has been considered. The view now accepted is that the bans imposed by the two clauses are independent and separate and each must separately be got over. In view of this, we are not required to travel beyond the first clause in this case.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Immunity Company Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: bans imposed by the two clauses of Art. 286 are independent and each must be separately got over

precedents.citation: M/s. Ramnarain Sons Ltd. v. Asst. Commissioner of Sales Tax and others 2

anchor.surface_text: Again, in M/s. Ramnarain Sons Ltd. v. Asst. Commissioner of Sales Tax and others 2 , it was observed as follows So far as article 286 1  a  is concerned, the Explanation determines by the legal fiction created therein the situs of the sale in the case of transactions coming within that category and when a transaction is thus determined to be inside a particular State it necessarily becomes a transaction outside all other States.

precedents.case_name: Ramnarain Sons Ltd. v. Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) determines situs of sale by legal fiction for transactions within its category; if inside one State, outside all others

precedents.citation: State of Mysore v. Mysore Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: This clause of the Article has been construed on previous occasions by this Court, and what is meant by the expression in the course of has been well. established. Indeed, in State of Mysore v. Mysore Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd. 1 , this Court observed that the point could no longer be said to be at large.

precedents.case_name: State of Mysore v. Mysore Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: construction of 'in the course of export' is well established and no longer at large

precedents.citation: State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. The Bombay Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Fortunately, there is less disagreement on this point than on the interpretation of the Explanation, and it is sufficient to refer to the leading decisions of this Court. The earliest case on the subject is State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. The Bombay Co. Ltd. 2 , where four possible meanings of the expression in the course of were considered.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Bombay Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'in the course of export': sale by export involves integrated activities from agreement with foreign buyer to delivery to common carrier; sale and export parts of single transaction

precedents.citation: State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory and Others 3

anchor.surface_text: The meaning of these observations was further explained in State of Travancore-Cochin and others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory and Others 3 . It was observed  p. 62  that the words export out of in this context did not refer to the article or commodity exported, and that the reference to the goods and to the territory of India made it clear that the words export out of meant the exportation out of the country.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
